value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Then when the house was built, & roads <del>led</del> often</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">flooded, often deep in mud, led <del>to</del> from house to house</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-anon" key="Anon">Anon</rs> came</del> along the roads, came the minstrels, the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">jugglers, the <del>singers</del>, bear leaders, singing their crude</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">songs at the back door, to the farm hands & the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">maid servants, in the uncouth jargon of <del>the</del> <add place="above">their</add> native tongue</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>English</del> <del>Upstairs they talked French</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="block">Icham for wore...</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Upstairs they spoke French. The <del>nature singer was</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">man at the back door was despised. <del>He</del> <add>[It?]</add> had no</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">name, no station <del>yet even the Kings & Queens</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>must have their singers, their actors.</del> He was</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">a <del>jester, a [illeg.]</del> <del>Perhaps</del> But even the Kings &</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Queens must have their minstrel, even if they</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">despised him, they tolerated him, as we tolerate</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">those who say out loud what we think, but will</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">not admit. If he <del>was</del> <add place="above">had</add> the outsiders</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">privilege, to say <del>the</del> <add place="above">to</add> mock<del>up</del> the <del>irreverent, the</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to comment; <del>to</del> He <del>too was the</del> to see</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">from the outside. He <del>preserved to the</del> old</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>stories. He</del> <del>he</del> As <del>time went on, he</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He put into words the things that were</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">remembered – the <del>old legends; the old</del> he</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>dan</del> <del>incited the peasants to</del> As time</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">went on, & <del>the</del> <del>there</del> houses were</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">grouped by the <del>road, a church</del>, he</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">& the church found in the [midst?], he</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">was to be found acting in the church;</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>he</del> <del>a</del> & then, when <del>his</del> as <del>his</del> acting</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">became more & <del>more definite</del> as he acted</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>himself</del> a more & more secular past, he</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">left the church, acted in the churchyard,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">& was at last admitted to the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">market place. But he was</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>the scholars</del> <del>have</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">nameless. <del>His songs were</del> <del>unwritten</del></l>
